cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerB: Is discouraged.
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: What is a retarder?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents a vehicle from going too fast
questions.answerB: A device that prevents a vehicle from being too loud
questions.answerC: A device that improves a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: Retarders help to slow vehicles, reducing drivers' need to use brakes.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The truck is properly loaded.
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: In order to receive a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must complete all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: An FBI fingerprint check.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass the HazMat knowledge test; undergo a Federal Security Threat Assessment; provide proof of U.S. citizenship or permanent residency; and undergo an FBI fingerprint check and federal criminal history background check.

questions.question: On flat surfaces, wheel chocks:
questions.answerA: Can be used to prevent a parked vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Make it easier for a parked vehicle to roll.
questions.answerC: Should only be used on the front driver's side tire.
questions.explanation: In situations where a driver cannot use a parking brake, wheel chocks can be used to hold a parked vehicle in place on a level surface.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is usually:
questions.answerB: Dangerous, due to the possible scent.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: When driving, how can you maintain alertness?
questions.answerA: Keep cool by using the air conditioner or opening a window.
questions.answerB: Eat a lot of heavy foods.
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming fatigued while driving include keeping the cab cool inside by using the air conditioner or opening a window; avoiding heavy foods; and taking rest breaks about every two hours or 100 miles.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to use your mirrors?
questions.answerB: You are making a turn.
questions.answerC: You are looking at fuel prices.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal driving routine, checking your mirrors is especially important when turning, changing lanes, merging, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication of standing water on the roadway?
questions.answerB: Portions of the pavement that are dry
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning can occur in places where water collects on the road. Clear reflections, tire splashes, or rain drops on the road can indicate the presence of standing water.

questions.question: To make it easier to leave a parked position, you should park:
questions.answerA: In a way that allows you to back up when exiting.
questions.answerB: In a way that allows you to pull forward when exiting.
questions.answerC: Only on the side of roadways, not in parking lots.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, look to park in a space that will allow you to pull forward when exiting.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.answerB: In the early evening
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Lower the tire's air pressure.
questions.answerC: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: After other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Before other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerC: At the same time as other parts of the roadway.
questions.explanation: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze before other road surfaces. When driving in cold weather, especially when weather conditions have been wet, use special caution on bridges and overpasses.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.answerB: Is distracting.
questions.explanation: Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage, so be sure to accelerate smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: If you will be transporting hazardous materials that require placards, you must:
questions.answerA: Ask permission of the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerB: Obtain a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to transport a material that requires placards.

questions.question: While driving, if you notice anything that affects safety or could lead to mechanical problems, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait to see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Include the concerns in your written report.
questions.answerC: Try to fix the issue yourself.
questions.explanation: After finishing a day of driving, you may have to complete a written report on the condition of your vehicle. Be sure to mention anything that could affect safety or lead to mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.answerB: Black ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet instead of icy. Always be on the lookout for black ice if a road surface looks wet and temperatures are around the freezing mark.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: The water compressor belt.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerB: Tire pressure is too low.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.answerB: Engine
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow the vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: How much distance will an air brake-equipped vehicle need to come to a complete stop if it is traveling at 55 mph under ideal driving conditions?
questions.answerB: 100 feet
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.answerB: About one-third.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.answerB: Air pressure.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long drives.
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: When taking a driving test:
questions.answerA: You must supply the same type of vehicle for which you will require a CDL.
questions.answerB: You may supply any type of vehicle, even if it is not the type of vehicle for which you will be using with the CDL.
questions.answerC: The testing station will supply the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Skills tests must be taken in the type of vehicle the applicant plans to drive. The applicant is generally responsible to supply the testing vehicle.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: Oversized loads:
questions.answerA: Can never be transported by a truck.
questions.answerB: Should only be transported during the day.
questions.answerC: Should receive proper authorization to ensure compliance with state and local laws.
questions.explanation: Special permits are required for loads that are over-size, over-length, or overweight.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Avoid using your mirrors while in heavy traffic.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look to the front, sides, and rear of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.answerB: Seven to eight
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need eight to nine hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you have a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: When transporting a load, you should inspect the cargo:
questions.answerB: At the end of each day.
questions.answerC: Every time you take a break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securement must be inspected every time you take a break during a trip. Be sure to inspect the cargo at least every 150 miles.

questions.question: When traveling in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerB: The speed of surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: A speed much slower than the flow of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to match the speed of surrounding vehicles. Vehicles traveling in the same direction at the same speed are unlikely to collide. However, you should not exceed legal speed limits.

questions.question: Without the proper amount of oil in its engine:
questions.answerA: A vehicle will have difficulty stopping.
questions.answerB: A vehicle will make quick, jerking movements while being driven.
questions.answerC: The engine may be quickly damaged.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a vehicle's engine have adequate oil pressure. An engine can be destroyed rapidly if it is run without oil.

questions.question: Steering wheel play of more than ____ can make steering difficult.
questions.answerB: 25 degrees
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: If you will be transporting hazardous materials that require placards, you must:
questions.answerA: Ask permission of the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerB: Obtain a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to transport a material that requires placards.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and/or on the sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Cracks in the tires
questions.explanation: Be sure to thoroughly inspect your tires before a trip. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut, cracked, or otherwise damaged in any way.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Repair the brakes.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to both sides of a CMV?
questions.answerB: Model number of the truck
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the USDOT number to both sides of each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is not required safety equipment?
questions.answerB: A liquid burning flare
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.answerB: Get some coffee.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: To prevent becoming an aggressive driver you should:
questions.answerB: Make gestures at other drivers.
questions.answerC: Give other drivers the benefit of the doubt.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in aggressive driving behavior, it is helpful to give other drivers the benefit of the doubt. Assume that they have valid reasons for what they are doing and don't take their actions personally.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerB: Be as quick as possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead of you:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to make a plan to avoid an upcoming hazard.
questions.answerB: Is not encouraged as it distracts you from driving.
questions.answerC: Is only important when traveling in congested traffic.
questions.explanation: Always watch for hazards on the road ahead. Doing this will allow you time to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: The weight of a truck:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on stopping distance.
questions.answerB: Is a major factor affecting stopping distance.
questions.answerC: Is not as important as the type of cargo in determining stopping distance.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's weight is an important factor affecting its stopping distance. The heavier a vehicle is, the more work the brakes will need to do to bring it to a complete stop.

questions.question: Using a helper when backing up a large vehicle is:
questions.answerB: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: Backing a CMV is always dangerous due to limited visibility, so using a helper to monitor your blind spots is encouraged whenever possible.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerB: Pressed down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.explanation: When stopping, it is best to gradually press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts could be loose.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerB: 100 feet of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerB: Use both side mirrors.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: Texting while driving should:
questions.answerB: Only be done in curves.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is a dangerous distraction and is prohibited at all times when operating a CMV.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Keep cargo in a large box.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from sliding in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from falling out of a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking may be used on all sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerB: Permits more weight for trucks.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: Escape ramps are ramps that can be used:
questions.answerB: To leave the highway and enter a two-lane highway.
questions.answerC: To stop runaway vehicles on steep downhills.
questions.explanation: Escape ramps are constructed in areas with steep downgrades to allow a means of safely stopping runaway vehicles. They consist of a long bed of loose, soft material, and sometimes an uphill slope.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerB: Using your senses
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerB: Pushing down quickly.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: To prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move, you can:
questions.answerA: Partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in second gear.
questions.answerC: Use the parking brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: To ensure that your vehicle does not roll backward when beginning to move after a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your right foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: A DUI conviction will result in loss of license for a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Six months.
questions.explanation: A first-time DUI conviction will result in the disqualification of your CDL for at least one year. A second offense will result in a lifetime disqualification.

questions.question: When starting an engine, warning lights and buzzers should:
questions.answerB: Flicker occasionally.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections:
questions.answerA: Should never be done the same way two times in a row.
questions.answerB: Should always be done in the same order.
questions.answerC: Do not need to be done if the driver thinks the vehicle is in good operating order.
questions.explanation: A vehicle inspection should be completed in the same order every time. This will make it easier for you to learn all of the steps and will make it less likely that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When applying for a hazardous materials endorsement, being found guilty of which of the following is a disqualifying offense?
questions.answerB: Speeding
questions.explanation: Amongst other crimes, a felony conviction for arson will disqualify a person from obtaining, renewing, or transferring a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.answerB: Properly using turn signals.
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to both sides of a CMV?
questions.answerB: Model number of the truck
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the USDOT number to both sides of each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Place weight over only the axles.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: If you must back up, it is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Drive as fast as possible to complete the maneuver quickly.
questions.answerB: First walk the line of travel to look for obstacles.
questions.answerC: Use only the passenger side mirror.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, you should exit the cab and check your path for obstacles before beginning the maneuver. Drive as slowly as you can, checking your mirrors on both sides.

questions.question: The weight of a truck:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on stopping distance.
questions.answerB: Is a major factor affecting stopping distance.
questions.answerC: Is not as important as the type of cargo in determining stopping distance.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's weight is an important factor affecting its stopping distance. The heavier a vehicle is, the more work the brakes will need to do to bring it to a complete stop.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Under-inflate your tires.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles have front brake limiting valves with "normal" and "slippery" settings. Setting a brake limiting valve to "slippery" reduces the vehicle's stopping power, so a driver should make sure the valve is in its "normal" position. Front wheel braking has proven to be effective in all driving conditions.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerB: Enjoy the scenery.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only needed for interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: The ____ are activated by an electric switch that is triggered by the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn signals
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerB: 4 psi
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a driver becoming tired?
questions.answerB: Drifting from their lane
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigued driving include difficulty focusing; frequent blinking or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing one's eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thinking; trouble remembering the last few miles driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping one's head up; drifting from one's lane; following a vehicle too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; and feeling restless or irritable.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: When taking the driving test and asked to make a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use a turn signal since you were told to make the turn.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only to your right.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: When starting an engine as part of a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Place the engine in first gear.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.answerB: About a minute
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerB: Lock up your vehicle's wheels.
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: A cargo van is:
questions.answerA: Usually the same height with or without a load.
questions.answerB: Usually taller with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.answerC: Usually shorter with a heavy load than with a light load.
questions.explanation: The added weight of a heavy load will make a vehicle sit lower than usual. A vehicle will often be taller when carrying a light load than when carrying a heavy load. If your vehicle fits under an overpass while carrying a full load, it is not guaranteed that it will fit under the same overpass if it is empty.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Always use turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Only use turn signals if there is a vehicle next to them.
questions.answerC: Not use a turn signal if a lane change is obvious.
questions.explanation: Always signal before turning or changing lanes to ensure that other drivers are aware of your intentions.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerB: Ignore their gestures.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: When driving down a steep hill, your primary source of braking should be:
questions.answerB: The brakes.
questions.explanation: On a steep downgrade, you must use the engine's braking effect as your primary method of speed control. Be sure to decelerate and downshift appropriately before beginning to drive down the hill. Relying too heavily on the brakes may cause them to overheat and fade, becoming less effective.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerA: Allowed if you are contacting your employer.
questions.answerB: Allowed when driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is dangerous and is never permitted while operating a CMV.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Cracks in the tires
questions.explanation: Be sure to thoroughly inspect your tires before a trip. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut, cracked, or otherwise damaged in any way.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerB: Usually has slowed perception.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire has remained clean.
questions.explanation: After changing a tire, you should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Two tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: Question others' driving abilities.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brakes?
questions.answerA: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Yawning repeatedly or rubbing eyes
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: On a slippery road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make turns as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Refrain from passing slower vehicles.
questions.explanation: Under slippery conditions, you should drive slowly and smoothly. Make turns as gently as possible and do not pass other vehicles unless you have to.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: Five inches
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When driving, mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Infrequently.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is surrounding your vehicle at all times. You should make a habit of regularly checking your mirrors while driving.

questions.question: Manual air tank drains should be:
questions.answerA: Opened to drain the tanks after each day.
questions.answerB: Left open while driving.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.answerB: A loud horn
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: When applying for a hazardous materials endorsement, being found guilty of which of the following is a disqualifying offense?
questions.answerB: Speeding
questions.explanation: Amongst other crimes, a felony conviction for arson will disqualify a person from obtaining, renewing, or transferring a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerB: The brakes are very cold.
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: When taking a driving test:
questions.answerA: You must supply the same type of vehicle for which you will require a CDL.
questions.answerB: You may supply any type of vehicle, even if it is not the type of vehicle for which you will be using with the CDL.
questions.answerC: The testing station will supply the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Skills tests must be taken in the type of vehicle the applicant plans to drive. The applicant is generally responsible to supply the testing vehicle.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: After starting the engine as part of a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Rev the engine.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The truck is properly loaded.
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Should be expected to be on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Is usually empty and harmless.
questions.answerC: Could contain a heavy object that could damage vehicles.
questions.explanation: Almost any foreign object on the road poses some potential danger. For example, even something as seemingly harmless as a cardboard box could contain a hard or heavy object that could damage your vehicle.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Roads are the most slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with the oil and grease on the road that have not yet washed away.
questions.answerB: Roads are naturally slippery.
questions.answerC: The gravel gets washed into the middle of the lane.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: When operating a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You are never required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if you are driving a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: A driver's seat should always be equipped with a seat belt. You must wear a seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.answerB: Two tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, your vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: Gravity causes a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling on a downgrade. Adjust your speed before reaching a downgrade.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.answerB: May not affect
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only required during interstate travel.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Overloading a vehicle with cargo:
questions.answerA: Usually has no effect on the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can impact the vehicle's steering and brake control.
questions.answerC: Can impact the vehicle's electrical system.
questions.explanation: Overloading a vehicle can have negative effects on steering, braking, and speed control. Learn to recognize when cargo is overloaded or poorly balanced.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible.
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: You must have an air brake endorsement:
questions.answerA: To use a vehicle with air brakes.
questions.answerB: To drive any truck with a trailer.
questions.explanation: You must take an air brakes knowledge test to become licensed to operate a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, including an air over hydraulic braking system.

questions.question: The heavier the vehicle:
questions.answerA: The less important the brakes become.
questions.answerB: The harder the brakes need to work.
questions.answerC: The quieter the brakes will sound.
questions.explanation: The heavier a vehicle is, the more the brakes will need to work to bring the vehicle to a complete stop.

questions.question: When should mirror adjustments be made?
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.answerC: When a vehicle is stopped at a traffic signal
questions.explanation: Mirror adjustment should be checked prior to the start of each trip. Any attached trailer should be straight while mirrors are being adjusted.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Wave an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should not use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: You should use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should not use your turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always use your turn signals and check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless it is being used to transport hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless it will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerC: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Texting while driving should:
questions.answerB: Only be done in curves.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is a dangerous distraction and is prohibited at all times when operating a CMV.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise toward the normal operating range.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: When traveling through a work zone, you should:
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Steer with one hand and keep the other hand free.
questions.explanation: Always observe posted speed limits for work zones. Slow down if road or weather conditions are adverse, and slow down even more if workers are on or near the road.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash down the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the other driver’s behavior to police.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: To stay alert while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Eat a heavy meal before beginning your trip.
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm.
